node.text:
Prof Kim Hyung-suk is a 102-year-old Professor who comes from the same village as the original ‘Great Leader’ of North Korea, Kim Il-Sung. 

In 1945, after Japan was expelled from Korea he had breakfast with the man who would go on to be the first leader of North Korea and the founding father of the Kim dynasty which still holds power to this day.

#BBCNews #NorthKorea

node.title: Breakfast with Kim Il-Sung, Korea's founding father.

node.text:
"It was a magical moment."
 
This extraordinary film shows a paddle boarder’s close encounter with two curious whales in Argentina.
 
The drone footage was captured by photographer Maxi Jonas who spotted the Southern Right Whales playfully swimming beneath the board of Analia Giorgetti.
 
She was on the water during her birthday and described meeting the two mighty mammals as a “privilege”.
 
#Whales #Cetology #SouthernRightWhales #BBCNews

node.title: Boarder's close encounter with curious whales

node.text:
Swedish pop superstars Abba have surprised and delighted fans by announcing their first studio album for 40 years.

Abba Voyage will be released in November, before a "revolutionary" set of concerts where virtual avatars will play hits like Mamma Mia and Waterloo.

The quartet, who split up in 1982, said they ended up back in the recording studio while working on the stage show.

"At first it was just two songs, and then we said, 'Well, maybe we should do a few others,'" said Benny Andersson.

#Abba #AbbaMusic #BBCNews

node.title: Pop legends Abba announce new music

node.text:
A state of emergency has been declared in New York City and New Jersey after they were hit by record rainfall and flash flooding as a result of Tropical Storm Ida.

Mayor Bill de Blasio said the city was "enduring an historic weather event" with "brutal flooding" and "dangerous conditions" on the roads.

#HurricaneIda #US #BBCNews

node.title: Deadly flash flooding in New York and New Jersey after Hurricane Ida

node.text:
"It's a need, and we can."
 
A mental health ambulance team in North West England have begun giving out food parcels to patients, who in some cases haven't eaten for days.
 
The British Dietetic Association say they are concerned about a rise in mental health patients across the UK going without food during the Covid-19 crisis.
 
See more on Ambulance @BBCiPlayer.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the project. 

#Ambulance #Covid #Help #BBCNews

node.title: Ambulance crew feed patients in need

node.text:
“I just want a fair chance and a fair shot to compete at my highest level.”

US athlete Blake Leeper, a double amputee, is already a Paralympic silver medallist and world record holder - and now wants to compete in the Olympics.

But after the rules were changed in 2018, the blades that Leeper had been running on for years were deemed too long for competition.

Instead of shortening his blades, Blake took World Athletics to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, arguing their measuring system was not only “discriminatory”, but that he believed the Olympics was simply “not ready for a disabled man, not only to compete, but win".

He lost his case. Meanwhile, World Athletics strongly denies his allegation that the rules are discriminatory based on race.

#Olympics #BBCNews

node.title: Why was this athlete 'too tall' to race?

node.text:
“I wasn’t a very nice person.”

Football fan Neil, 56, says he was a racist and a bigot until his daughter Millie showed him that his behaviour was unacceptable.

He said he used to go along with racist chants at football matches, but is ashamed of his former behaviour and now describes himself as "anti-racist".

#Racism #BBCNews

node.title: 'I used to be a racist bigot'

node.text:
Taliban fighters entered Kabul airport within hours of the last US soldier leaving Afghanistan.

The militant group has been filmed celebrating on the tarmac with their leaders making a congratulatory speech.

Fighters were quick to investigate military equipment left behind, with some posing and taking pictures in aircraft.

#Afghanistan #Taliban #BBCNews

node.title: Taliban celebrate entering Kabul airport by posing in aircraft

node.text:
Female news anchor Beheshta Arghand made headlines when she interviewed the Taliban, days after they took control of Afghanistan.

Two weeks later, she fled the country amid fears for her life.

"I'm so unhappy, because this generation really worked, really struggled for a new Afghanistan. I so miss my job, my country."

Tap the link in our bio for more stories from other Afghans forced to leave their homes - and their dreams behind.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.title: Female journalist who interviewed Taliban flees Afghanistan

As taekwondo makes its debut at the Paralympic Games in Tokyo, two South Korean Para-athletes say that the sport has given them hope and energy.

node.text:
Tens of thousands of people have been evacuated from the shores of Lake Tahoe in northern California as a major wildfire continues to spread.
 
More than 3,500 firefighters have been deployed to combat the Caldor Fire, which began more than two weeks ago, and has burned more than 191,000 acres.
 
The US Forest Service has also announced the closure of all Californian national forests until 17 September to stop the spread of wildfires.
 
Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the devestating fire.

#CaldorFire #California #LakeTahoe #BBCNews

node.text:
Across the world, women have been posting slogans on streets, walls and buildings to raise awareness of femicide and fight against everyday sexism.

The number of women in the UK killed or suspected of being killed by men in 2021 has reached 100, according to data collated by Counting Dead Women, a Femicide Census project.

The slogan campaign was started by a lone activist in Paris, and has spread in the UK too.

The women who go on pasting missions risk a fine if they're caught, but say it's a way for their voices to be heard.

#Feminism #Women #BBCNews

node.title: Tackling violence against women with slogan posters

node.text:
Prof Kim Hyung-suk is a 102-year-old Professor who comes from the same village as the original ‘Great Leader’ of North Korea, Kim Il-Sung. 

In 1945, after Japan was expelled from Korea he had breakfast with the man who would go on to be the first leader of North Korea and the founding father of the Kim dynasty which still holds power to this day.

#BBCNews #NorthKorea

node.text:
From fabulous facial expressions to powerful poses - the finalists in the 2021 Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards know how to work the camera. 🤩

In addition to providing some light-hearted relief, the competition aims to highlight the important message of wildlife conservation in an engaging and positive way.

The winners will be announced at an awards ceremony on 22 October.

Tap the link in our bio for many more comedy snaps.

(📷Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards)

Photo 1 - Laughing Snake by Aditya Kshirsagar
Photo 2 - Monday Morning Mood by Andrew Mayes
Photo 3 - Don't worry. Be happy! by Axel Bocker
Photo 4 - Directing penguin by Carol Taylor
Photo 5 - Time for school by Chee Kee Teo
Photo 6 - The Baboon who feels like a tenor by Clemence Guinard
Photo 7 - The Green Stylist by Gurumoorthy K
Photo 8 - I guess summer's over by John Speirs
Photo 9 - I got you by Roland Kranitz

node.text:
Jacob Anthony Chansley - the QAnon Shaman - was one of thousands of Trump supporters who took part in the Capitol Hill riot.

Nearly 600 people have been charged in the federal investigation of the riot, which was an attempt to prevent the US Congress from certifying Joe Biden as president, beating Donald Trump.

Chansley became the de facto face of the siege, pictured amid the chaos in horns and a bearskin headdress, with the American flag painted on his face. He called himself the "QAnon Shaman".

QAnon is a wide-ranging conspiracy theory whose followers believe former President Donald Trump was waging a secret war against elite Satan-worshipping paedophiles in government, business and the media.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the case against those who took part in the Capitol Hill riots.

(📷 Getty Images)

#BBCNews

node.text:
Podcast host and UFC commentator Joe Rogan has announced he has Covid.

Earlier this year he faced backlash for suggested that young, healthy people did not need the coronavirus vaccine. However, he later clarified he was "not an anti-vax person" and believed “they're safe and encourages many people to take them."

Rogan, 54, told his 13.1 million Instagram followers he was recovering but would have to postpone his next show.

"We immediately threw the kitchen sink at it, all kinds of meds," he said, listing a string of medicines including the deworming drug ivermectin, which health experts say has yet to prove effective against Covid. He added that, three days on, he felt "great".

To read more about Rogan and vaccination rates in the US, tap the link in our bio.

(📷 Getty Images)

#JoeRogan #Covid #Coronavirus #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 03, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'BBNES BBC NEWS Banksy piece back on sale after being partially shredded'.

node.text:
Three years ago the art world was stunned when Banksy ‘Banksy-ed’ them, by shredding one of his works as it was sold.

The work “Girl With Balloon” was voted the UK’s favourite artwork in 2017, this version is now called “Love Is In The Bin” after the piece self-destructed.

The anonymous artist secretly installed a shredder into the frame in case it went up for sale, and as the £1.1million price was locked in at the auction the piece was cut up.

Tap the link in bio to read more about the sale of the new piece, which could now go for more than £4 million.

(📷 Banksy/Instagram, Getty Images)

#Banksy #Artwork #BBCNews

An aerial view of abandoned tents at Reading Festival

node.text:
Tents and camping equipment discarded by revellers at Reading Festival are set to be distributed to refugees in France.

Herts For Refugees collected 2,300 tents and 500 sleeping bags from Little John's Farm, the site used to host the annual music festival in Berkshire, UK.
 
The items would be "life-saving" for refugees living at French ports in Dunkirk and Calais, the charity said.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about this story and how music festivals hope to combat the problem of abandoned tents.

(📷 Reuters)

#ReadingFestival #MusicFestivals #BBCNews

node.text:
"It was a magical moment."
 
This extraordinary film shows a paddle boarder’s close encounter with two curious whales in Argentina.
 
The drone footage was captured by photographer Maxi Jonas who spotted the Southern Right Whales playfully swimming beneath the board of Analia Giorgetti.
 
She was on the water during her birthday and described meeting the two mighty mammals as a “privilege”.
 
#Whales #Cetology #SouthernRightWhales #BBCNews

node.text:
Swedish pop superstars Abba have surprised and delighted fans by announcing their first studio album for 40 years.

Abba Voyage will be released in November, before a "revolutionary" set of concerts where virtual avatars will play hits like Mamma Mia and Waterloo.

The quartet, who split up in 1982, said they ended up back in the recording studio while working on the stage show.

"At first it was just two songs, and then we said, 'Well, maybe we should do a few others,'" said Benny Andersson.

#Abba #AbbaMusic #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 03, 2021. May be an image of 5 people.

node.text:
England footballers faced racist abuse from Hungary fans during their 4-0 World Cup qualifier win in Budapest.

Manchester City forward Raheem Sterling and Borussia Dortmund midfielder Jude Bellingham were both targeted.

Several players were pelted with plastic cups and other objects, which Declan Rice and Jack Grealish used in turn to poke fun at Hungary fans by taking celebratory ‘drinks’ following England goals.

Uefa ordered Hungary to play three home games behind closed doors after fans' discriminatory behaviour at Euro 2020.

But home supporters were allowed in to the Puskas Arena as this match fell under Fifa jurisdiction.

The tone was set at kick-off when England's players were booed loudly as they took a knee to protest against racism.

Hungary's players and their head coach Marco Rossi had asked supporters to respect England's gesture before the match but the message went unheeded.

Tap the link in our bio for more reaction to events on and off the pitch.

(📷 EPA/Getty)

#WorldCup #Hungary #England

node.text:
Chinese para-swimmer Zheng Tao has won the internet after shattering records and winning four gold medals at the Tokyo Games - despite having no arms.

"Daughter, look at me - I can swim so fast even though I don't have arms!" he said in a video message to his two-year-old.

The 30-year-old, who lost his arms to an electric shock as a child, dominated with wins in freestyle, backstroke and butterfly. All of his individual golds have been world or Paralympic records.

Online, social media users were wowed by his upper body strength and called him a "true inspiration" and a "source of pride".

Tap the link in our bio for more on his inspirational journey.
 
(📸: Getty Images)

#Tokyo2020 #Paralympics #BBCNews

node.text:
A state of emergency has been declared in New York City and New Jersey after they were hit by record rainfall and flash flooding as a result of Tropical Storm Ida.

Mayor Bill de Blasio said the city was "enduring an historic weather event" with "brutal flooding" and "dangerous conditions" on the roads.

#HurricaneIda #US #BBCNews

"It's a need, and we can."
 
A mental health ambulance team in North West England have begun giving out food parcels to patients, who in some cases haven't eaten for days.
 
The British Dietetic Association say they are concerned about a rise in mental health patients across the UK going without food during the Covid-19 crisis.
 
See more on Ambulance @BBCiPlayer.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the project. 

#Ambulance #Covid #Help #BBCNews
